title: Fortnite goes dark after dramatic season finale leaving 5.5 million gamers stunned
text:
More than five million gamers were left dumbfounded on Sunday as the 10th season of the popular Fortnite went out with a bang.

Fans of the hit Epic Games program wondered if their cherished game was deleted as the island that plays host to the online battle royale was destroyed - leaving nothing but a black hole.

But have no fear, Fortniters. The game will be back for season 11 with a brand new map, according to Forbes.

Fortnite, released by U.S.-based Epic Games in 2017, allows up to 100 players to fight individually or as part of a team to be the last standing on a virtual battlefield.

Fans of the online gaming hit Fortnite are reeling from the surprise ending of season 10 on Sunday

More than 5.5 million gamers witnessed 'The End' - the event that brought an end to season 10

A giant meteor hit the island, destroying everything in sight and leaving nothing but a black hole

It has become the most popular online game in the world, played by some 250 million people, including in tournaments with big cash prizes.

Sunday was a special day for players, who were eager to see ‘The End’ - the event that marked the finale of this season.

A meteor struck the island, obliterating the map at around 2pm Eastern time.

Players who have logged into the game since then found themselves staring at a blank screen, making them wonder if the plug has been pulled entirely.

But gamers should not worry, as there will be a season 11 with an entirely new map. The old map is seen above

Fans online were in disbelief over what they witnessed as they tried to make sense of the surprise ending

'Is Fortnite over?' wondered one Twitter user on Sunday

Millions of people regularly watch Fortnite on YouTube, Twitter, and Twitch.

Online gaming experts say the end wasn’t a total shock, as there have been hints throughout the entire season that the map would be replaced.

Adding to the confusion on Sunday was the fact that the official Twitter account of Fortnite deleted all of its tweets.

The shock ending prompted gaming enthusiasts to wonder if Elon Musk had bought Fortnite only to delete it - as the Tesla chairman joked in a tweet from last year.

Last year, Elon Musk tweeted a fake news item which claimed that he bought Fortnite just to delete it because he wanted to 'save these kids from eternal virginity'

Musk on Sunday teased online gamers, tweeting 'Haha' in reaction to the season finale

The search term 'Elon Musk buys Fortnite' began to trend on Google.

Last year, Musk retweeted a fake news article headlined: ‘Elon Musk buys Fortnite and deletes it.'

Musk then teased online gamers by retweeting the link, writing: 'Had to be done ur welcome.'

But gaming experts assure fans that Musk did not have anything to do with Sunday's event.
description: Fans of the hit Epic Games program Fortnite wondered if it was deleted as the island that plays host to the online battle royale was destroyed - leaving nothing but a black hole.
